Award.AwardTitle: Graphene-SiC Interface: Effect of Atomic Bonding Type on Thermal Transport

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET - 1235852
PI: Xinwei Wang, Iowa State University

In this project, a novel technology based on steady-state joule heating and simultaneous Raman spectroscopy will be developed to measure and distinguish the temperature between graphene and its substrate. This technology enables nanometer resolution in the out-of-plane direction for thermal mapping. Systematic knowledge will be built about thermal transport between graphene and SiC, and how this interface thermal resistance is affected by two typical interfaces: interface featuring Van der Waal force and interface with covalent bond. Atomistic modeling will be conducted to evaluate the graphene-interface thermal resistance and complement the experimental data to provide a cross-benchmarked and complemented in-depth and full-spectrum picture of the thermal transport at graphene-SiC interface. For thermal design in graphene-based devices and systems, this project will establish an important quantitative knowledge base about the interface thermal resistance sustained by Van der Waals and covalent bonds.

Broader impacts. The results of the research will be integrated into existing and new courses at Iowa State University. Undergraduate participation in summer research will be facilitated through the PERUSE program at ISU. Outreach to K-12 students is included, and will involve supervision of independent study projects by top students from local high schools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The overarching goal of the project is to study the interface thermal resistance between graphene and SiC via new technology development, structure analysis, and physics study in comparison with other 2D atomic layer materials. The objectives of the proposed research are to: 1) Develop a novel technology for direct probing of phonon energy transport across graphene-substrate interface, 2) Characterize the interface thermal resistance and investigate the effect of interface atomic bonding, and 3) Conduct atomistic modeling to understand the physics behind the effect of interface atomic bonding  on phonon energy transport. We have developed a novel dual-laser steady-state technology to measure the temperature drop across the graphene-substrate interface and characterized the local thermal resistance. The measurement revealed poor thermal contact between graphene and the substrate, and the results were successfully explained by the local interface spacing via studying the local optical interference. More importantly, we have developed a new technology to measure the interface thermal resistance of 2D atomic layer materials without the need of laser absorption and temperature rise data. This technique has tremendous advantages over the current technologies whose measurement uncertainties are very large due to the known sample-to-sample variation of optical properties and the local interface spacing.

 

With the partial/full support of this project, seven Ph.D. students have received excellent training on micro/nanoscale material structure characterization, physics modeling, experiment design, and data analysis. Four of them have graduated (two female). Two of them (female) have become assistant professors in China universities. Four of them have won the Iowa State University Research Excellent Award, and one has won the prestigious 2016 Zaffarano Prize at Iowa State University. The research results were also integrated into graduate level Heat Transfer (ME536) teaching and Engineering Thermodynamics class teaching. With the full/partial support of this project, 32 papers have been published in highly visible journals. They are also listed on the PI’s lab web for broader access. Lab tours have been arranged for high school students, undergraduate students, and graduate students, and to provide hand-on experience for them on micro/nanoscale material characterization and measurement. Also we have provided independent project conduction and training to seven undergraduate students.
